Procurement.definition: Manages sourcing, supplier relationships, and purchasing decisions across the organisation.
Procurement.green_skills_focus: Embedding decarbonisation, circular procurement, and ESG supplier performance management.
Procurement.example_green_jobs: Sustainable Procurement Manager, Scope 3 Data Analyst, Circular Supply Chain Lead.
Procurement.risk_of_not_upskilling: Regulatory non-compliance, supply chain disruption, reputational damage, missed cost-saving opportunities.

Finance.definition: Oversees budgeting, financial planning, reporting, investment decisions, and risk management.
Finance.green_skills_focus: Integrating ESG risk assessment, sustainable finance, and climate disclosure capabilities.
Finance.example_green_jobs: Green Finance Analyst, ESG Reporting Lead, Climate Risk Officer.
Finance.risk_of_not_upskilling: Investor disengagement, regulatory penalties, stranded assets, reduced access to capital.

Marketing.definition: Develops and delivers brand, product, and customer communications.

Marketing.risk_of_not_upskilling: Greenwashing claims, reputational damage, loss of customer trust, regulatory fines.

IT.definition: Provides technology infrastructure, systems, and data management across the business.
IT.green_skills_focus: Green IT practices, ESG data management, AI for sustainability optimisation.

IT.risk_of_not_upskilling: Increased digital emissions, data integrity risks, inability to meet disclosure requirements.

Legal.definition: Manages legal risk, compliance, contracts, and governance.

Legal.risk_of_not_upskilling: Litigation exposure, non-compliance fines, reputational harm, board-level liability.

Supply Chain.definition: Plans, manages, and optimises the flow of goods, services, and materials.

HR.definition: Supports recruitment, talent development, culture, and organisational effectiveness.

Operations.definition: Delivers core production and service processes to meet customer and business needs.

• Greenwashing litigation risk: Increased regulatory scrutiny and consumer lawsuits demand lawyers who can assess and defend green claims
• Governance liability: Board-level ESG accountability means lawyers must advise on fiduciary duties linked to sustainability
• Client expectation gap: Clients increasingly expect ESG legal expertise as a core service, not a niche specialism
• Data quality and access: 42% of lawyers cite ESG data quality challenges as a key driver of complexity
• Talent gap: Legal teams lack structured green skills training pathways, with much upskilling still informal or ad hoc
sectors.why_green_skills_matter: Green skills transform legal professionals from reactive compliance advisors into strategic sustainability counsel. Lawyers who understand CSRD, climate disclosure frameworks, and circular economy policy can guide organisations through the transition, reduce litigation exposure, and advise boards with authority. As ESG regulation becomes the dominant growth area in commercial law, green skills are a core commercial differentiator.

sectors.overview: The financial services sector faces an accelerating green skills gap that threatens both net zero commitments and regulatory compliance. Green job postings in financial services grew nearly tenfold as a proportion of all FS postings since 2019, but graduates and existing professionals are not keeping pace.
sectors.pain_points:
• Mandatory disclosure overload: TCFD, CSRD, SFDR, EU Taxonomy and ISSB S1/S2 standards require finance teams to build entirely new climate reporting capabilities
• ESG data quality: CFOs struggle to integrate finance and sustainability data, with European teams reporting significant quality and governance challenges
• Stranded asset risk: Portfolios with high carbon exposure face growing write-down risk under climate scenarios
• Greenwashing and mis-selling: Green bond and ESG fund claims face regulatory scrutiny, requiring robust ESG knowledge across product teams
• Skills pipeline deficit: Graduate programmes have not historically included sustainability, leaving a structural shortage of green-literate finance professionals
• Culture and buy-in: Until recently, sustainability and finance teams operated in silos — integration requires cultural as well as technical change
sectors.why_green_skills_matter: Financial services is a key lever in the entire economy's transition to net zero. Banks, insurers and asset managers that embed green skills across all functions — from portfolio management to risk assessment to product design — are better placed to manage regulatory risk, attract ESG-conscious capital, and support clients through the transition. Green skills in finance are now a licence to operate in an increasingly disclosure-heavy market.

sectors.overview: Manufacturing accounts for approximately 20% of global CO2 emissions and is under intense regulatory and supply chain pressure to decarbonise. The sector faces a dual challenge: reducing its own Scope 1 and 2 emissions while managing complex Scope 3 emissions embedded in materials and products. WEF's Future of Jobs Report 2025 ranked climate mitigation as the third most important transformation driver for businesses globally.
sectors.pain_points:
• Scope 1, 2 and 3 complexity: Most emissions sit in the supply chain (Scope 3), requiring manufacturers to influence upstream and downstream partners without direct control
• Carbon border adjustment: EU CBAM creates cost implications for energy-intensive producers, requiring carbon accounting capabilities across the business
• Materials transition: Shifting to low-carbon, recycled or bio-based materials demands R&D, procurement and operations teams to develop new technical skills
• Energy management: Rising energy costs and net zero commitments require facility managers and engineers to rethink energy use from the ground up
• Circular design mandate: Extended Producer Responsibility and EU Ecodesign regulations require manufacturers to design for end-of-life from day one
• Workforce perception: Younger workers view manufacturing as outdated, making it harder to attract green-skilled talent
sectors.why_green_skills_matter: Manufacturing must undergo the most fundamental operational transformation of any sector to reach net zero. Green skills — from energy efficiency and lifecycle assessment to circular design and Scope 3 management — are not optional extras; they are the technical competencies that will define which manufacturers remain competitive through the transition. Companies that invest now in green upskilling across production, engineering and procurement will outperform those that wait for regulation to force change.

sectors.overview: Fast-moving consumer goods companies and retailers sit at the intersection of consumer demand, regulatory pressure and complex global supply chains. On average, 80% of a consumer goods company's emissions come from its supply chain, and over 90% of other environmental impacts. The sector faces overlapping pressures from greenwashing regulation, packaging law, biodiversity requirements and mandatory CSRD disclosures.
sectors.pain_points:
• Greenwashing regulation: EU Green Claims Directive and UK CMA greenwashing guidance create significant legal and reputational risk for marketing and product claims
• Packaging compliance: Extended Producer Responsibility and the EU Packaging Regulation require reformulation of entire product ranges
• Scope 3 complexity: Vast, multi-tier supply chains make emissions tracking, deforestation-free sourcing and human rights compliance operationally challenging
• Consumer scrutiny: Gen Z and Millennial consumers are more likely to reject brands perceived as greenwashing, raising the stakes for sustainability authenticity
• CSRD and double materiality: Companies within scope must publish audited sustainability reports from 2025, requiring capability across every function
• Biodiversity and nature: Ingredient sourcing tied to deforestation, water stress and soil degradation creates emerging regulatory and reputational exposure
sectors.why_green_skills_matter: FMCG and retail businesses need green skills embedded across procurement, marketing, operations and finance to manage a uniquely visible and consumer-facing sustainability challenge. Getting sustainability wrong in this sector carries immediate reputational damage and regulatory penalty. Getting it right creates genuine brand differentiation, consumer loyalty and access to ESG-linked capital. Green skills enable teams to move beyond tick-box compliance to authentic, commercially valuable sustainability leadership.

sectors.overview: The sports industry has an outsized cultural platform and a significant — and largely underreported — environmental footprint. A typical NFL game produces approximately 35 tons of waste. Three global sporting events (2010 FIFA World Cup, 2014 FIFA World Cup, 2016 Rio Olympics) together generated 10.05 million tonnes of CO2e. The Paris 2024 Olympics set a new benchmark by targeting a 50% reduction in carbon footprint from prior Games, demonstrating what green skills embedded across planning, procurement and operations can achieve.
sectors.pain_points:
• Fan travel and event emissions: Transportation dominates event carbon footprints, typically 70–90% of total emissions, yet is largely outside organisers' direct control
• Venue construction and operations: Stadium builds are carbon-intensive, and existing venues require significant retrofitting for energy and water efficiency
• Broadcast and digital footprint: Live streaming, digital advertising and broadcast infrastructure contribute growing but undertracked emissions
• Supply chain complexity: Sports apparel, equipment and merchandise supply chains have significant environmental and labour issues — the sports apparel and fashion sector is the world's second-largest industrial polluter after aviation
• Greenwashing risk: Some organisations have made carbon-neutral claims for events that lack credible methodology, attracting regulatory and media scrutiny
• Sponsorship alignment: As sustainability criteria enter sponsorship and brand partnership decisions, sports organisations without credible ESG programmes risk commercial disadvantage
• Lack of standardised frameworks: Unlike finance or manufacturing, sports lacks universally adopted sustainability reporting standards, making benchmarking and accountability difficult
sectors.why_green_skills_matter: Sports organisations that develop green skills across their workforce can credibly manage their carbon footprint, design more sustainable events, and leverage their unique cultural influence to inspire fans, sponsors and communities. Green skills enable sports professionals to go beyond tokenistic pledges and build programmes that achieve measurable emissions reductions. As major sponsors increasingly require ESG alignment, green-literate commercial and operations teams become a revenue protection and growth capability.
